author: CBD
title: No Glory as Benny Elias and Tony Sage lose Indonesian play Kupang Resources
text:
Illustration John Shakespeare
The corporate ref has finally blown the whistle on the Indonesian explorer run by rugby league legend Benny Elias and Perth Glory owner Tony Sage : Kupang Resources.
A small army of administrators and receivers has been appointed this week after its marathon tussle with spurned litigation funder Paul Lindholm – and the tax man – finally came to an end.
It would have been as gutting as any grand final loss for the code-crossed buddies in what has been a very drawn out encounter.
It all began back in 2012.
Advertisement The High Court awarded Lindholm's International Litigation Partners (ILP) a $10 million pay day against Kupang – then known as Chameleon Mining – after the Elias-controlled company dispensed with Lindholm's litigation funding services and got into bed with Sage.
The settlement included $5 million up front and another $5.5 million payable in monthly instalments, plus interest.
All was going well until February 2013, when the Tax Office came knocking on Kupang's door with a $7.2 million bill from Lindholm's ILP.
Kupang was ordered to redirect its ILP payments to the ATO.
In August last year, Lindholm's ILP appointed receivers to Kupang, citing the payment switch to the Tax Office as a breach of the settlement.
Sage told the ASX the request was invalid "in that it required Kupang to act contrary to the notices issued by the Australian Tax Office".
Kupang obtained a stay of execution while the lawyers battled it out in the courts.
Kupang finally threw in the towel this week, after the most recent court decision found it was in default because the company, low on cash, could not pay the Tax Office under the terms it agreed with ILF.
Silver lining The resource community is showing once again how desperation breeds innovation.
Digging up dirt is expensive, but how do you get the mother lode without digging?
Silver explorer Black Mountain Resources has found a solution. It plans to finance a salvage expedition to "execute the recovery of of major gold and silver cargoes from two British passenger ships sunk during World War I", according to Black Mountain's executive director, Peter Landau .
Apart from the need for floaties, it is sheer genius.
The mother lode has already been dug up, and refined. And then sunk.
An estimated 1.8 million ounces of gold coins and bullion is sitting in the holds of the two ships. Another 6.35 million ounces of silver is also on offer if time permits.
The value of the gold cargo on the SS Arabic alone has been estimated at $US1.4 billion.
"These vessels were sunk in a major shipping lane in international waters south of Ireland while attempting to deliver bank transfers to North America to finance the war effort," Black Mountain reported.
While there have been unsuccessful attempts to salvage the loot from the SS Arabic and TSS Hesperian in the past, the team from Black Mountain's partner, IDM Exploration Ltd, have "new research" and the "latest technology" to succeed where others got scuppered.
And the good news is that Black Mountain investors will find out pretty soon if the salvage operation is a winner.
The salvage crew is heading off next month to make the most of the small operational window that will close by October, thanks to local weather conditions.
Black Mountain reports that it has the option of claiming 20 per cent of the salvaged loot by footing the bill for $4 million of costs.
It should be a minor hassle for a silver explorer with a $1 million market cap.
Rising ambition He may not have bragging rights to a casino, but cosmetic surgeon turned hotel mogul Jerry Schwartz has beaten James 'Mr Carey' Packer to the punch when it comes to actually watching the first concrete pour on his $360 million hotel at Sydney's Darling Harbour precinct.
Jerry helped smooth the first bit of concrete along with his young son, Dane, watched by NSW Trade Minister Stuart Ayres , who copped an earful about Schwartz's quixotic plans to build a helipad on the roof.
And how else will it ever host a Liberal Party fundraiser.
"It's 35 storeys high, who's going to complain – the neighbours?" he said, referring to the very public failure of his earlier plans for a floating helipad on the harbour.
We hope the latest heliport campaign gets a better hearing than his 2013 plans to turn Sydney's disused monorail stations into giant fish tanks.
